{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3016969,"name":"CartesianRobotics","username":"Cartesian","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/a6a055/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-03-04T19:59:41.929Z","cooked":"

After we finished the cabling process we had a problem with the motors. The motors were connected to PWM SPARK MAX and after creating a controller object in code we set the motor to 0.
(motor.set(0)) But even though we set it to 0 the motor turns and stops by itself. When we delete the motor controller object from the code and upload an empty code the problem stops. We tried to change the mode of the controller it didn’t work. What might be the problem

We are sure the controller was blinking dark blue but once the motor started turning it turned into green and then when it stoped back to blue

So PWM has reliability issues.
PWM works on the idea that rapidly oscillating the signal on and off can send a signal; in this case, the percent output. However, noise in the wires is occasionally interpreted as signal, and this causes outputs.
The deleting it from the code stopping the problem is weird. Have you considered just using the sparkmax over CAN?

Go to this website and click on the download thing if you are using java, or labview. This is where you will find your spark max thing you need. I use labview so after it finished downloading I exit out of labview and every tab in labview but if you all ready did then go to your program and right click and go to the WPI libary and find Thrid party can and you will see it I think. but I hope this was helpful. REVLib Information - SPARK MAX

Which language are you using?
https://docs.revrobotics.com/sparkmax/software-resources/spark-max-api-information
You need the RevLib installed and then you just use CANSparkMax motor = new CANSparkMax(id);
It will require rewiring the motor controllers on to the CAN bus and then using the Rev hardware client to set the CAN ids. However, since REV is trying to sell these, they have developed pretty good documentation.

Turns out the problem is really about the PWM connection. We tested roborio and spark controllers separately and they both work fine. When we switched to CAN connection everything started to work perfectly. I suggest every team use CAN because it is much easier to wire and it is also quite organized compared to PWM.
